conclusion: Shadows are created when an object blocks light from a source, and their position and size depend on the angle and distance of the light source relative to the object and the surface.
The image shows three objects casting shadows labeled A, B, and C.
Object corresponding to shadow A: A birdcage (top left).
Object corresponding to shadow B: A small cylindrical object (top right).
Object corresponding to shadow C: A drumstick or similar object (bottom left).
The current light source appears to be positioned somewhere above and slightly to the left of the objects, as the shadows are cast to the right and downward.
The shadow of an object is cast in the direction opposite to the light source relative to the object.
The size of the shadow depends on the angle of the light rays.
If the light source moves to the right, the shadows will shift to the left.
When the light source moves closer to being directly above the object, the shadow tends to shrink because the light rays become more parallel, reducing the spread.
If the light source moves farther to the side, the shadow can elongate due to the increased angle of incidence.
The light source is now to the right above the objects, causing the shadows to shift to the left.
Shadow A (from the birdcage) will move to the left of its current position.
Shadow B (from the cylindrical object) will move to the left of its current position.
Shadow C (from the drumstick) will move to the left of its current position.
As the light source moves to the right, the angle between the light rays and the objects will initially increase, potentially elongating the shadows further.
If the light source moves directly above the objects, the shadows will shrink because the light rays will be more vertical, reducing the spread.
The light source moving horizontally to the right while remaining at a similar height would likely elongate the shadows slightly more and shift them leftward.
The birdcage (A) has a complex shape, so its shadow will shift left and may elongate or distort depending on the new light angle.
The cylindrical object (B) will cast a shadow that shifts left and may stretch along its length.
